metadata.preacher: Not explicitly mentioned (delivered at All Saints Church, Princeton)
metadata.sermon_start_end: This Sunday at All Saints is called Outreach Sunday, or Mission Sunday. The word “outreach” is a rather trendy recent addition to the Christian vocabulary. [...] This power to reach out in Christ is the door to heavenly life. And just in case there were to be any doubt about it, we have in today’s Gospel lesson the promise of our risen Lord himself: Truly, truly, I say to you, he who believes in me will also do the works that I do; and greater works than these will he do, because I go to the Father. AMEN.
metadata.liturgical_context: The Fifth Sunday of Easter, May 2, 1999
metadata.historical_context: Delivered shortly after the Columbine High School massacre (April 20, 1999) and during the Kosovo War/NATO bombings.
metadata.notes: The sermon bridges the gap between the high theology of the Resurrection and the practical 'Outreach Sunday' of a local parish.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon utilizes strong, evocative imagery, particularly in the 'soul-searing' depiction of God calling out to Adam. The preacher effectively employs Paul Scott Wilson's 'show, don't tell' principle by using the personal anecdote of the Virginia Legislature. The contrast between the 'smoothly oiled Byrd Machine' and the 'pieces of grit' (Young Turks) creates a tactile sense of political friction. The use of the 'dustbin of the Roman Empire' for the crucifixion provides a gritty, concrete image of Christ's solidarity with the marginalized. While some metaphors are traditional (Red Sea, slavery), they are revitalized by being linked to contemporary 'unfortunates.' The imagery of the 'incandescent climax' of the church year adds a sensory, light-based quality to the liturgical season.
quotes: Adam, attempting to hide, hears the voice of God saying, 'Adam, where are you?' This is one of the most soul-searing utterances in the entire Scripture.
The Young Turks were pieces of grit in the smoothly oiled Byrd Machine.
Jesus took upon himself... a human outcast, thrown onto the dustbin of the Roman Empire.
strengths: Effective use of narrative anecdote to create a visual setting (the gallery of the Legislature).
Strong sensory language regarding the 'stench' of political indifference ('untouched and untroubled').
Vivid personification of God as an 'anguished parent' seeking a lost child.
improvement_points: The 'outreach' metaphor could be more physically developed—the act of 'reaching' remains somewhat abstract in the middle section.
The 'bomb and bomb' imagery regarding Kosovo is powerful but could benefit from more specific sensory detail to avoid becoming a political cliché.
The 'incandescent climax' is a beautiful phrase that could have been woven more deeply into the visual texture of the sermon.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strong 'showing' in the personal anecdote and the Genesis scene; more 'telling' in the sociological section regarding Orlando Patterson.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is exceptionally precise and demonstrates what Marilyn Chandler McEntyre calls 'stewardship of language.' The preacher carefully deconstructs the shift from 'mission' to 'outreach,' noting the loss of apostolic weight in the latter. There is a clear refusal to hide behind 'Canaanite' jargon; instead, theological terms like 'diakonia' and 'recapitulate' are introduced with clarity and purpose. The analysis of the term 'unfortunates' is a masterclass in linguistic precision, exposing how a single word can function as a tool of distance and dehumanization. The prose is economical, avoiding the 'beautifying writing' Grözinger warns against, favoring instead a sober, sharp clarity that does justice to the gravity of the Columbine and Kosovo contexts.
quotes: He referred to the residents of the hospitals as 'these unfortunates.' ... You could tell that he looked upon 'these unfortunates' from a great distance.
The word mission comes from a Latin root meaning to send.
By reaching out to others, we recapitulate the prior outreach of God to us.
strengths: Excellent diagnostic of how language (e.g., 'unfortunates') reveals the heart's posture.
Clear, unpretentious explanation of theological roots (mission/diakonia).
Avoidance of empty superlatives; the gravity of the subject matter is carried by the precision of the nouns.
improvement_points: The transition into the Orlando Patterson quote is slightly academic and could be more seamlessly integrated into the sermon's poetic flow.
The phrase 'our collective goose was cooked' is a bit of a jarring colloquialism in an otherwise high-register text.
The ending quote from John 14:12 is powerful but could have been preceded by a more precise 'bridge' sentence.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological jargon is minimal and always serves to clarify the 'sending' nature of the gospel.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a natural cadence suited for oral delivery. There is a rhythmic repetition of the phrase 'reaching out' and 'God reached out,' which acts as a liturgical refrain. The sentence structure varies effectively, moving from the long, courtly descriptions of the Virginia Legislature to the staccato, urgent mentions of the Kosovo bombings and the Columbine massacre. The use of the hymn lyrics ('Christ is risen, we are risen!') provides a melodic anchor that lifts the prose into a higher, more celebratory register toward the conclusion. The 'peroration' of Paul is mirrored in the preacher's own building momentum in the final third of the text.
quotes: The church exists by mission as fire exists by burning.
We seem to be unable to think of anything better to do than bomb and bomb and bomb some more.
Christ is risen, we are risen! shed upon us heavenly grace … That with hearts in heaven dwelling, we on earth may fruitful be.…
strengths: Strong use of parallelism ('not simply of black poverty but of the nation’s poverty').
Effective rhetorical use of the 'refrain' regarding God's outreach.
The sermon 'breathes' well, with pauses for reflection built into the narrative structure.
improvement_points: Some of the middle paragraphs (the Deuteronomy section) are slightly dense and could benefit from more rhythmic variation.
The transition from the Macedonian camp story back to the 'sour grapes' proverb is a bit abrupt.
The final 'AMEN' feels slightly tacked on after the long scripture quote; a final rhythmic sentence of the preacher's own would have been stronger.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Distinctly oral language; the use of 'Well,' and 'You know how we Virginians are' indicates a text written for the ear.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The sermon exhibits a high degree of micro-aesthetic quality. It avoids the 'beautifying' trap by using language that is both sober and evocative. The preacher's 'stewardship of words' is most evident in the deconstruction of the term 'unfortunates,' which serves as the aesthetic and moral pivot of the piece. The imagery is concrete and grounded in both biblical narrative and personal history, creating a 'living' metaphor for grace. While it occasionally leans into academic citation, the overall rhythm is that of a seasoned orator who understands the power of the spoken word to 'frame' reality.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a sophisticated 'Homiletical Plot' as described by Eugene Lowry. It begins with a 'trendy' word (Outreach) and moves into a deep upsetting of the equilibrium through the story of the Byrd Machine and the 'unfortunates.' This personal story serves as a 'parable' for the human condition. The tension builds as the preacher connects this indifference to the global tragedies of Columbine and Kosovo. The turning point (the 'peripeteia') is the Resurrection—not as a static fact, but as a 'power' that turns the world upside down. The movement from 'they' to 'us' provides a clear dramaturgical resolution that leads directly to the 'altar call' of the collection for the saints. It is a dynamic journey from social indifference to cosmic solidarity.
quotes: I never really trusted the Byrd Machine after that...
What is the Christian gospel? You know what it is. We were all unfortunate.
This Resurrection power is now given to the Christian community. Our labor is not in vain.
strengths: The personal anecdote is perfectly timed to create a 'crisis of perception' for the hearer.
The integration of current events (Columbine/Kosovo) creates a high-stakes environment.
The move from the 'small' (grandson/donation) to the 'cosmic' (Resurrection) is handled with great skill.
improvement_points: The transition from the Deuteronomy laws to the Virginia anecdote is a bit of a 'jump' that could be smoothed.
The ending relies heavily on a long scripture quote, which slightly dissipates the narrative energy built up in the previous paragraphs.
The 'Outreach Sunday' theme is occasionally a bit too 'on the nose,' threatening to make the sermon feel like a committee report.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from a local anecdote to global tragedy to cosmic victory.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest strength. It exemplifies Johan Cilliers' concept of 'reframing.' The preacher takes the context of 1999 (post-Columbine, Kosovo War) and reframes it through the lens of the Resurrection and the Exodus. The 'they' vs. 'us' sociology is not just presented as a good idea, but as a theological necessity because 'Jesus became us.' The biblical text (Deuteronomy and 1 Corinthians) is not used as a springboard but as the very 'optics' through which the congregation is invited to view the 'nerds, geeks, and dweebs' of their own world. The synthesis is organic; the 'unfortunates' of the Virginia Legislature are directly mapped onto the 'unfortunates' of the human race redeemed by Christ.
quotes: By reaching out to others, we recapitulate the prior outreach of God to us.
In Christ, all of the 'theys' have become 'us' because Jesus became 'us.'
This Resurrection power is now given to the Christian community... This is more power than any bomb.
strengths: Masterful 'reframing' of the 'unfortunate' label into a universal theological category.
The connection between the collection for the saints and the local 'Outreach Sunday' is seamless.
The sermon respects the 'strangeness' of the Resurrection while making it immediate to the Kosovo context.
improvement_points: The 'Byrd Machine' context might be too specific for a modern audience, though it worked for the 1999 Princeton congregation.
The 'Doctors Without Borders' mention is a bit brief; it could have been more deeply tied to the 'reaching out' imagery.
The 'sour grapes' proverb is introduced but not fully 'reframed' in light of the Resurrection.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes; it successfully reframes 'charity' as 'recapitulation of the Resurrection.'

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: While the sermon is aesthetically rich, it leans toward a more 'closed' structure. The preacher provides very clear, definitive answers to the problems raised. The 'they' become 'us' is presented as a completed reality ('the cycle has been broken... it has been broken'). While this provides strong comfort, it leaves less room for the 'ambivalence of existence' or the 'resistance' that Ciska Stark mentions. The hearer is guided quite firmly toward a specific interpretation of the gospel's social implications. However, the 'openness' is found in the invitation to the 'greater works' at the end—the sermon ends not with a period, but with a commission that the hearer must fulfill in their own life.
quotes: The Christian gospel is that this cycle has been broken. Not can be broken; it has been broken.
We unfortunates have no power in and of ourselves to break the cycle.
God willing, leadership may arise out of this congregation to make this ministry still more effective.
strengths: The ending is an invitation to action, which opens the sermon into the life of the hearer.
The use of 'we' and 'us' throughout prevents the sermon from being a 'closed' lecture to 'them.'
The acknowledgment of the 'tiny things' (small actions) respects the hearer's limited capacity.
improvement_points: The 'it has been broken' section could leave more room for the painful reality that the cycle *feels* very much unbroken in Kosovo and Columbine.
The sermon could benefit from more 'open questions' that allow the hearer to wrestle with their own 'Byrd Machine' allegiances.
The conclusion is quite triumphant; a moment of 'sustained tension' regarding the 'not yet' of the Resurrection would add depth.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: More of a 'witness' (Long) than an 'open work' (Stark); it is monovalent in its proclamation of victory.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic quality is strong, characterized by a clear narrative arc and masterful integration of text and context. The preacher avoids a static three-point structure in favor of a 'dynamic journey' that links personal memory, global tragedy, and cosmic hope. The 'reframing' of the congregation's identity from 'donors' to 'redeemed unfortunates' is the structural heart of the sermon. While the structure is somewhat 'closed' by its triumphant Easter theology, it succeeds in taking the hearer from the 'gallery' of the observer to the 'arena' of the participant.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon successfully avoids religious kitsch by refusing to offer 'cheap comfort.' The preacher stares directly at the 'unspeakable inhumanity' of the Kosovo war and the 'pathologies' of Columbine. By identifying the congregation (and herself) as 'unfortunates,' she avoids the kitsch of the 'heroic' Christian helping the 'poor.' The emotion regarding the Virginia Legislature feels authentic because it is rooted in a loss of innocence and a realization of complicity, rather than a sentimental 'happy ending.' The sermon sustains the tension of the 'unloved alienated young men' without offering a simplistic 'Jesus is the answer' bandage that ignores the root causes.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'collective goose was cooked' phrase borders on a kitschy colloquialism that slightly devalues the gravity of the Fall.
The mention of the 'blond and handsome' grandson could veer into sentimentality if not quickly tied to the discipline of kindness.
authentic_moments: The deconstruction of the 'courtly debates' that hid a cold indifference to the 'mentally retarded.'
The raw dialogue between the Macedonian father and son about killing Serbs.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain the 'sober beauty' of the Reformed tradition by continuing to ground high theology in the 'grit' of political and social reality.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Space for grace is opened primarily through the 'reframing' of the human condition. By placing everyone—preacher, congregation, and 'weirdos'—in the same category of 'unfortunates' who were 'slaves in Egypt,' the preacher removes the moralistic barriers that usually block grace. The 'Space for Grace' (Cilliers) is created in the 'between' of the Resurrection victory and the ongoing 'labor' of the church. However, the space is slightly crowded by the sociological analysis toward the end, which moves from the 'mystery of God' toward 'sociological pathology.'
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between the 'mighty cosmic drama' and the 'minuscule gestures' of the congregation is well-sustained.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The mystery of the Resurrection is respected as an 'unthinkable' event that 'no one could have made up.'
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails; even the 'work' of the Lord is framed as a participation in God's prior outreach rather than a moral duty.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To create even more space, allow for a moment of silence or 'lament' for the victims of Columbine before moving to the 'victory' of the Resurrection.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically sophisticated example of 'New Homiletic' preaching, blending narrative, imagery, and a strong 'reframing' of reality. Its primary strength lies in its 'stewardship of language'—the way it takes a single word ('unfortunates') and uses it to dismantle the congregation's sense of superiority. The preacher avoids the 'kitsch' of Outreach Sunday by grounding mission in the 'grit' of the Resurrection and the 'dustbin' of the cross. The structure is dynamic, moving from the personal to the global with a rhythm that is both courtly and urgent. While the theology is firmly 'closed' in its Easter triumph, the sermon opens space for the hearer to see their own small actions as part of a 'mighty cosmic drama.' It is a 'sober-Reformed' aesthetic that finds beauty in the simplicity of 'reaching out' and the radicality of 'turning the world upside down.'
strengths_top_3: The 'unfortunates' linguistic diagnosis as a pivot for the entire sermon.
The masterful integration of the 1999 historical context (Columbine/Kosovo) with the Exodus/Resurrection narrative.
The use of personal anecdote (Byrd Machine) to illustrate a theological shift in perception.
improvement_points_top_3: Greater use of 'open questions' to allow the hearer more interpretative space.
Smoothing the transition between the Deuteronomy exegesis and the Virginia narrative.
Reducing the reliance on long, external quotes (Patterson/Bearak) in favor of more original 'imagery' in the final third.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Space for Grace) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to an educated, socially conscious congregation that values both intellectual precision and narrative depth.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with a more 'open' ending that leaves the 'greater works' as a haunting question.
Deepen the sensory imagery of the 'new world' to match the vividness of the 'old world' Byrd Machine story.
Read the text aloud to identify and smooth out the more 'academic' sociological passages.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically strong performance that succeeds in 'reframing' the mundane act of a church collection into a participation in the Resurrection. It avoids the pitfalls of kitsch and moralism by staying close to the 'unfortunate' reality of the human condition while persistently pointing to the 'outreach' of God. It is a model of how to preach 'contextually' without losing the 'strangeness' of the Gospel.
